awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Impact Resistant Equine Hoof - Structure, Properties and Bioinspired Designs
awd_abstract_narration:
Keratin is a protein found on the outer covering of most animals, such as hair, nails, horns, hooves, beaks, and feathers. Keratinous materials are among the most robust biological materials, which have been optimized by nature for their functions. For example, horse hooves are impact resistant while being lightweight. The hooves can withstand powerful and dynamic forces, but the fundamental reasons that give rise to this property are not known.  This research will significantly advance understanding of how hooves absorb energy and pave the way to build new impact-resistant, bioinspired materials. Designs by bioinspiration involve using ideas from nature and employing synthetic materials to create new engineering composite structures. Impact resistant materials are essential for a wide range of applications, which include body protection (body armor vests and helmets), defense (blast resistant structures), automotive industry (crash-resistant vehicles), aerospace (aircraft bird strikes), and space exploration (protection against space debris).  This transdisciplinary research and educational program involving mechanical engineers, materials scientists, and biologists, includes the experimental and computational studies of keratin-based biological systems and designs and fabrication of new engineering materials with a superb energy absorption performance during high-speed impacts. The participating graduate students will be paired with undergraduate researchers during the academic year and high school students during the summer. Inclusion of underrepresented minority and women students is planned. The graduate students will have the unique experience of getting trained and using powerful instruments at national laboratories. 

The objectives of this research project are to test the following hypotheses:
1. The hierarchical structure of hooves assists in energy absorption and resists high-speed impacts, 
2. Multiscale modeling can predict the compression and impact behaviors of hooves,
3. Synthetic hoof-inspired materials will have outstanding impact resistant properties.
This research integrates concepts and methods from diverse fields (biomechanics, materials science and engineering, and biology). The methods and approaches include the state-of-the-art characterization of keratin-based materials (small and wide angle X-ray scattering, nano-and micro-computed tomography, small angle neutron scattering, electron microscopy, nano- to macroscale mechanical testing), development of new constitutive models, and designing, building and testing of impact resistant bioinspired materials based on the exceptional properties of hooves. This project's approach is transformative as it incorporates ideas from nature (accelerates discovery), utilizes a computational materials science approach (generates data) to screen parameter space and create a catalog of structure-property relations, and employs neural network approach to find optimal designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Materials shape our world and influence nearly every aspect of our lives. The progress of our society is intimately tied to materials. Thus, there is a continued need to discover new materials for existing and emerging technologies. Equine hooves have outstanding impact resistance, which enables high-velocity gallop over hard terrain with minimum damage. In this collaborative research, conducted by our two groups (at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the University of California San Diego), we studied the hierarchical structure of a hoof wall (Figure 1) and explored compression and impact behavior of a hoof wall. Then, we used the knowledge we gained as inspiration to design high-impact, resistant, hoof-inspired structures for various technological applications.

Intellectual Merit:

This research is transformative because it addressed an underexplored natural system (the equine hoof wall), brought ideas from nature, advanced modeling of biological materials, utilized state-of-the-art experimental techniques, and used novel mathematical tools (topology optimization and machine learning) to design optimal impact-resistant structures. This interdisciplinary research, bridging biology, materials science, mechanics, and computer science, brought a new understanding of energy-absorbing mechanisms in natural systems and translated it to the engineering setting.

Our scientific achievements include the characterization of the key components of the hoof wall structure at different length scales, measurement of viscoelastic (time-dependent) of a hoof wall at different hydration levels, the creation of computational (finite element) models of the hoof wall to understand how different structural scales affect the impact resistance. We conducted impact tests on the hoof wall to identify failure mechanisms resulting from its complex and hierarchical structure. We found the interplay between the lamellae and tubular arrangements at different impact energies. We noted how the physical entanglement between the tubular reinforcement and matrix can lead to crack bridging, blunting, and arresting while strengthening the interphase region. We characterized the hoof wall microstructures, including the tubules changing spatially in shape, density, and size, and incorporated these designs into the bioinspired systems. Figure 2 shows the micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) image of tubules (visualizing porosity) in a hoof wall. Micro-CT imaging and analysis of impact tests that we did in situ using a synchrotron at the Advanced Light Source at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory showed how the intricate hoof wall structure helps to mitigate damage. Compact tension tests suggested that the tubular reinforcement increased energy absorbed by cracks while the hoof wall microstructure provided toughness (resistance to fracture).

 

These findings on a hoof wall's structure, composition, and mechanical properties at different structural scales and hydration levels guided the hoof-inspired designs. We created computational models employing finite element analysis, topology optimization, and machine learning to simulate synthetic hoof-inspired impact-resistant materials and structures and seek optimal designs. Then, we 3D-printed these structures using a multi-material printer to study their deformation mechanisms and responses and validate our designs. Lessons learned about the structure-property relations of the hoof wall can be applied to other biological systems. For example, many other natural systems, such as dentin in teeth or wood, have tubule geometries. Testing of the impact resistance of tubular architectures within the hoof wall will provide insight into the role of these arrangements in other systems found in nature.

Broader Impacts:

This project provided multiple educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and outreach activities for K-12 students and the general population. Six graduate students and several undergraduate students, including three women, were involved in this project. We trained the students in an interdisciplinary environment bridging biomechanics, biology, and materials science, and they conducted experiments and modeling. The students wrote journal and conference papers, presented at conferences and research group meetings, and participated in mentoring and outreach activities. They also gave guest lectures on materials in an introductory course on materials. Students who worked on this project received positions in industry or continued their studies. For example, one undergraduate student continued to pursue her Ph.D. studies at MIT while another went to study for another Ph.D. degree (in biology).

Also, this project contributed in several ways to the development and dissemination of new educational materials. We implemented the findings from this research in several regular courses, short courses, seminars, and outreach activities and created a dedicated website. Finally, we published our research results in sixteen refereed journal papers, one book chapter, and several conference papers.

Finally, the findings from this research can further guide designs of new high-performance materials for human, product, and infrastructure protection, with broad medical and technological applications spanning body armor, helmets, packaging, automotive components, electronics, aerospace, and space structures.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2024
Modified by: Iwona M Jasiuk
